texts.shortText:
Very small worms that live in minute, coiled, white, calcareous shells that are firmly cemented by one side to rocks, shells or other hard surfaces. The head bears a small number of usually bright-red, feathery feeding appendages and when the worm retracts the aperture is closed by a funnel-shaped, stalked operculum.

In reality there are a large number of similar species that fall into several genera, but as these require microscopic examination and a good deal of skill to separate, we treat the entire group as a unit here.
Coiled shell typically about 2 mm in diameter.

Global: The group is cosmopolitan.

Local/Regional: Found throughout the region.

Certainly the most common of all polychaete worms and found in enormous numbers (of many thousands per square meter) on virtually all hard surfaces, including rocks, mollusc shells, the exoskeletons of larger crustaceans and the fronds of larger algae, as well as virtually all man-made structures placed into the sea!
Filter feeders, removing fine particulate material from the water passing thought the crown of tentacles.

Cross-fertilizing hermaphrodites and brood the eggs inside the tube, releasing the eggs at an advanced stage of development, such that they spend only a few hours in the water before settling on nearby surfaces. Grow to maturity within about 2 months and lifespan is typically about a year.

The minute size and coiled shell identify the group, but there are numerous species, some that are fairly easily distinguished in that, for example, they have ridged or anticlockwise–coiled shells, but most of which require expert examination to identify to species level.
